module.p: beagan small amount, little, few is a masculine generic quantity noun, derived from the adjective beag small, little.

In terms of the stuff being quantified, beagan generally works like other generic quantity nouns –
When the stuff being quantified is new information, it is usually expressed as a noun modifier/specifier of beagan, either the genitive singular of a mass noun or the genitive plural of a count noun eg.
Dh’òl Raonaid beagan fìona. Rachel drank a little wine.
Tha beagan chon aig Màiri. Mary has a few dogs.
[...] ’Se glé bheag de chobhair a thug a’ Phàrlamaid a riamh do ’n Ghàidhlig no do fhoghlum agus do litreachas na Gàidhlig. Cuin a chualas ball-Pàrlarnaid a’ togail a ghuth a dh’ iarraidh leasachaidh do staid Gàidhlig ann an Albainn? Am bi cothrom a nis aig cuideigin a ghuth a thogail, anns an t-suidheachadh iongantach a th’ againn anns a’ Phàrlamaid ùr? Chan eil sinn ag iarraidh air an duine so, ma tha e ann, a’ Ghàidhlig a chur air thoiseach air lòn is obair is caitheamh-beatha an t-sluaigh. Chan eil sinn ag iarraidh ach beagan ceartais.
[...] The Parliament has given very little assistance ever to the Gaelic language or to Gaelic education and literature. When has a member of Parliament been heard raising his voice to demand improvement for the state of Gaelic in Scotland? Will someone have an opportunity now to raise his voice, in the unexpected situation we have in the new Parliament? We are not asking of this person, if he exists, >to prioritise Gaelic over food and jobs and the population’s standard of living. We only want a modicum of justice. td. 9, ‘Air an Spiris’
[...] ’Se madainn bhòidheach foghair a bh’ ann—tioram, le ceileir eòin, is beagan dealt air an fheur. Bha a[m] muir ’s na tighean ag éirigh á inntinn an latha. [...]
[...] It was a beautiful autumn morning – dry, with the chirping of birds, and a little dew on the grass. The sea and the houses were rising from the mind of the day [??]. [...] td. 169, le Iain Mac a’ Ghobhainn
Bha beagan airgid aige ’s mar sin chaith e a bheatha a’ sgrìobhadh, gun feum aige air obair eile a dhèanamh.
He had a little money and therefore he devoted his life to writing, without the need to do other work. td. 103
An e seo mo bheatha, arsa mise rium fhìn. A’ dol dhachaidh le beagan deocha orm air an rathad seo air a bheil mi cho eòlach, ann am baile far a bheil mi air a bhith fuireach airson bliadhnachan.
Is this my life, I said to myself. Going home with a little drink in me on this road which I know so well, in a village where I have lived for years. td. 54
Gun teagamh, dh’fheumadh tu beagan eòlais airson nan dreuchdan ud.
Without doubt, you would have to have a little expertise for those jobs. td. 27
Chan eil ach beagan chàirdean aige.
He only has a few friends.td. 43
When the stuff being quantified is already known, it is usually introduced by the partitive preposition de of governing a specified (ie. ‘definite’) noun eg.
Dh’òl Raonaid beagan den fhìon. Rachel drank a little of the wine.
Cheannaich Màiri beagan de mo choin. Mary bought a few of my dogs.
When the stuff being quantified is already known, and has just been referred to, or can be inferred, beagan can occur on its own eg.
Dh’òl Raonaid beagan. Rachel drank a little.
Tha beagan aig Màiri. Mary has a few.
’S ann a’ call bu tric’ a bha Uisdean, agus ged a bha e fhèin is Sandaidh a’ cosnadh beagan an-dràsta ’s a-rithist, ’s ann a’ dol dhan toll a bha iad am bitheantas.
Hugh lost [money] frequently, and although he and Sandy earned a little now and again, they were usually in debt. td. 55
Alternatively, beagan can be followed by one of the de prepositional pronouns eg.
Dh’òl Raonaid beagan dheth. Rachel drank a little of it.
Tha beagan dhiubh aig Màiri. Mary has a few of them.
beagan mu (dheidhinn) a little [information/knowledge] about some topic eg.
Tha Màiri ag iarraidh cluinntinn beagan mu choin. Mary wants to hear a little about dogs.
beagan ri (dhèanamh) a little to do eg.
Tha beagan ri dhèanamh aig Raonaid. Rachel has a little to do.

However, there is some variation in usage to be found here.
Ged a bha a’ ghrian air a dhol fodha, bha am feasgar blàth, ciùin, agus bha beagan de cheò air cruinneachadh sna h-àitichean ìosal.
Although the sun had set, the evening was warm and calm, and a little mist had settled in the low-lying areas. td. 44

beagan can also be used to modify a comparative adjective eg.
Tha Seumas beagan nas beairtiche na tha Dòmhnall. James is a little richer than Donald [is].
“Spunc,” ars esan a rithist, ’s e tighinn beagan na b’fhaisge orm.
“Spunk,” he said again, coming a little closer to me. td. 39
“Tha e beagan nas aosta na mi fhìn,” arsa mise, “’s chaidh an aghaidh aige a losgadh sa chogadh.”
“He is a little older than me,” I said, “and his face had been burned in the war.” td. 47

And sometimes a non-comparative adjective as well.
Tha mi a’ faireachdainn beagan sgìth ma dh’fhaodte.
I am feeling a little [bit] tired perhaps.td. 43

beagan can be emphasised by fìor.
Cha do choinnich sinn ach fìor bheagan de mhuinntir a’ bhaile.
We met but very few of the townspeople.Mark (2004) td. 67

Miscellaneous usages –
beagan eile a little more
Cha bu mhiste seo beagan eile de chùram.
This would be none the worse of a little more care.td. 67
am beagan the little
... a’ gluasad anns a’ bheagan gaoithe ...
... moving on the little wind (that there was) ...Watson (2001) td. 43
Thug e am beagan a bha aige fhèin seachad do chàch.
He gave the little [that] he had himself to others.Mark (2004) td. 67
with prepositions or adverbs
... beagan ro àm an Dealachaidh ...
... a little before the time of the Schism ...td. 67
... beagan shìos fodham ...
... a little below me ...td. 67
... beagan os cionn ...
... a cut above ...td. 67
beagan is a little more than
Bha am balla beagan is còig troighean.
The wall was a little more than five feet.td. 67
Chan eil ach beagan is seachdain bhon d’fhuair iad e.
It’s only a little over a week since they got it.td. 67
a lìon beagan is beagan little by little
A lìon beagan is beagan mar a dh’ith an cat an sgadan.
Little by little as the cat ate the herring.td. 67
bi air bheagan + gen have a little of something
Bha feadhainn a bha air bheagan Gàidhlig.
There were some who had little Gaelic.td. 67–8
Bha iad air bheagan bidh(e).
They had little food.td. 68
Tha mi coma ged a bhithinn air bheagan bìdh.
I don’t care if I would have little food.td. 68
Bha e air bheagan maith.
It was of little worth.td. 68
duine air bheagan tuaireim/cèille
a man of little sensetd. 68
air bheagan adhbhair
for little reasontd. 68
